content.webTitle: Said & Done: Cellino’s great job; fairytale glitter; and The Godfather

fields.headline: Said & Done: Cellino’s great job; fairytale glitter; and The Godfather
fields.bodyText: Man of the week Massimo Cellino - still working on his day-one pledges: “Leeds fans have had enough of eating shit and shutting their mouths …they’ve had to put up with 10 shitty years - I want to make them proud again.” Son Edoardo says his dad is “doing a great job … I’d say to fans, keep the faith.” Advice of the week Sepp Blatter, on tour in Moscow, sizing up a possible political boycott of Russia 2018: “This is football [not politics]. A boycott never achieves anything and does not have a positive effect. Fifa supports Russia.” Proving his point: a promotional 2018 Fifa video showing the Crimean peninsula as Russian territory. Fifa apologised for any offence. Other highlights from the launch: 1) Sepp’s explanation of 2018’s new “fairytale glitter” logo: “It unites magic and dreams.” 2) Vladimir Putin on what visiting fans can expect: “We will be hospitable … security will not create any problems or discomfort.” Putin’s proviso, as set out in January: “[Gay people] can feel relaxed here. But please, leave children alone.” War on racism update New last week: 1) Uefa reviewing the sanctions they imposed on CSKA Moscow for more racist fan violence – cutting their stadium ban from three games to two, and their fine from €200,000 to €100,000. Last month Michel Platini said Uefa were showing Fifa the way. “With Uefa, unlike at the World Cup, zero tolerance really is put into practice.” 2) Russia’s FC Rostov coach Igor Gamula responding to questions over whether he plans to sign Cameroon’s Benoît Angbwa. “We’ve got enough black players, we’ve got six of the things and you want me to sign a seventh?” Among his objections: “We’re playing badly. I think it’s Ebola.” 3) An 11-year-old boy banned from football in Italy for two months for making “racial insults” towards a referee in a Tuscany youth game – a sanction based on anti-discrimination guidelines set out by Italy’s FA and its president, Carlo “banana eaters” Tavecchio. Candidate of the week Peru FA head Manuel Burga – upset after rivals tried to use a new set of money-laundering allegations to stop him winning a fourth term. Burga says the claims are just “bullying, like I often get around election time. Let’s close ranks against this meanness.” • Burga’s last election win: 2011 – achieved after a last-minute change of voting rules. Burga, whose acceptance speech was interrupted by a colleague’s phone ringing with the theme from The Godfather, said corruption allegations were “laughable … it all just comes with the territory”. Plus: moment of the week Fifa’s general secretary Jérôme Valcke threatening Nigeria with suspension from all international football due to its inability to organise credible democratic elections. Manager of the week Greece, September: OFI Crete’s Italian manager Gennaro Gattuso shouts at the Greek press in English: “No leave. Leave what? Leave what? It’s too easy for me leave. No, me stay here.” 26 October: Leaves. 27 October: Comes back. “I’m loved here. How can I leave?” Most joined up PR McDonald’s corporate headlines last week: 1) A reported extended deal with Fifa, taking their official partner status into the Qatar World Cup; and 2) A reported new official slogan launching next year, urging the public to see the good in things: “Lovin’ Beats Hatin’’’. Least joined up PR “I don’t know what Twitter is. I wouldn’t want to read it. It doesn’t interest me one bit. I don’t know where you get it” - Harry Redknapp, star of last year’s #AskHarry Q&A day. QPR called Harry a social media pioneer: “It’s rare that managers take time out to engage.” Meanwhile: one to watch The FA’s plan, floated last month, to name Rio Ferdinand as their candidate to be Britain’s new Fifa vice-presidential candidate. Harry welcomed the idea. “Rio’s a smart, top boy. He’s a great role model. He could be another Platini, that’d be nice for him.” Clarification of the week Italy: Sampdoria president Massimo Ferrero clarifying his attack on Inter’s Indonesian owner Erick Thohir as “that Filipino”. Ferrero: “I meant no disrespect to Mr Thohir, Inter’s directors or the people of the Philippines – with whom I have a wonderful rapport.” Legal news Croatia: Dinamo Zagreb president Zdravko Mamic fined €17,000 for defaming lawyer Ivica Crnic during a 2013 tribunal. The court ruled Mamic’s extended questioning – “Why are you st-st-st-stuttering? Liars stutter. You’re a monster, a creep; you’re not your father’s son, you’re a pathetic mouse” – was “not reasonable”. Mamic: “I meant nothing by it.” Best philosophy Brazil: Model Carol Muniz, 28, on continued scepticism over her love for FA president Marco Polo Del Nero, 73. “Let them talk; this love is pure. You know, the Dalai Lama once spoke of truth and authenticity. That’s how I live my life.” Plus: moving on Argentina: Model Amalia Granata, ex-partner of striker Cristian “Ogre” Fabbiani, on life’s lessons so far. “I would never go out with a footballer again because they’re very young, and they’re assholes. Politicians though? Perhaps.”
